docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the speech today in Nashua, N.H., by Senator John McCain of Arizona declaring his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency: I do not announce my candidacy to satisfy my personal ambitions. My life has already been blessed more than I deserve. I don't begin this mission with any sense of entitlement. America doesn't owe me anything. I am the son and grandson of Navy admirals, and I was born into America's service. It wasn't until I was deprived of her company that I fell in love with America. And it has been my honor to serve her and her great cause -- freedom. I have never lived a day since that I wasn't more than thankful for the privilege.

headline.main: Excerpts from McCain's Speech Declaring Candidacy

docs.lead_paragraph: When a famous person is found to have a serious and potentially fatal disease, it often serves as a wake-up call for the rest of us. Just as Nancy Reagan's breast cancer stimulated a rush for mammography, the recently diagnosed colon cancer of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court should jolt all women (and men) over 50 -- and some younger people as well -- to take advantage of the tests that can detect this disease while it is still curable, perhaps even before it has become cancer. Cancer of the colon and rectum is the second leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States, after lung cancer. It is also one of the most curable of cancers, but only if it is found in its early stages. Because colorectal cancer usually develops over many years and has a long precancerous stage, it can be detected early and even prevented if people adhere to recommended screening guidelines.

headline.main: Detecting Colon Cancer When It Is Curable

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on cancer of colon and rectum, second leading cause of cancer deaths in United States; says it is one of most curable of cancers, but only if found in early stages; says early state colorectal cancer is often silent disease, producing no symptoms, which is why periodic screening is so important; says contrary to popular opinion, disease hits women as well as men; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a vast public education campaign, the biggest in the 34-year history of Medicare, the Federal Government is mailing handbooks this month to the 39 million Medicare beneficiaries to try to guide them through the increasingly complicated world of health care. Backed up by toll-free telephone service, (800) 633-4227, an expanding Internet site (www.medicare.gov) and outreach efforts with more than 200 local and national groups, the new campaign is intended to aid an aging population that experts say is often ill-equipped to handle the brave new world of health care choices envisioned by Congress.

headline.main: Extensive Effort Seeks to Clarify Medicare Maze

docs.abstract: Federal Government mails handbooks to 39 million Medicare beneficiaries to try to guide them through inceasingly complicated world of health care; new campaign, biggest in 34-year history of Medicare, includes toll-free telephone service, expanding Internet site and outreach efforts with more than 200 local and national groups; it is intended to aid aging population that experts say is often ill-equipped to handle new world of health care choices envisioned by Congress; challenge facing new campaign is daunting; many experts say there is significant confusion among elderly about costs and benefits of various health plans (M)
docs.snippet: In a vast public education campaign, the biggest in the 34-year history of Medicare, the Federal Government is mailing handbooks this month to the 39 million Medicare beneficiaries to try to guide them through the increasingly complicated world of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Though it was little noticed at the time, a donnybrook over Senate rules last week illustrated the outsized role of special interests in government. The issue was a money grab by oil businesses, which want to lower the royalties they have to pay the Government for drilling on Federal land. When Senator Russell Feingold of Wisconsin tried to block an amendment that would let them keep their royalty payments artificially low, and pointed out that oil-sector campaign donations were calling the shots, several senators objected. Their reason? Mr. Feingold's recitation of campaign donations was not ''germane'' and therefore not allowed during the debate. How quaint of the senators to disparage the germaneness of campaign contributions. In fact, nothing could be more relevant than the power of donors to call the tune in Congress. Fortunately, Mr. Feingold was allowed to continue, in spite of complaints from Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas, the amendment's sponsor, and Senator Craig Thomas of Wyoming. Unfortunately, the measure passed. The bill to which it is attached contains objectionable anti-environmental features, and President Clinton should veto it.
docs.abstract: Editorial says bill that would lower royalties oil businesses must pay to Government for drilling on Federal land illustrates outsized role of special interests in government; says Sen Russell Feingold was right to point out that oil-sector campaign donations are calling the shots; says it is perverse for Senate to cut school aid, housing and other domestic programs on ground that budget must be balanced, then cut revenues even more by handing big break to oil companies; says Pres Clinton should veto bill and Senate should impose ban on unlimited 'soft money' contributions to political parties
docs.snippet: Though it was little noticed at the time, a donnybrook over Senate rules last week illustrated the outsized role of special interests in government. The issue was a money grab by oil businesses, which want to lower the royalties they have to pay the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The union seeking to represent the Metropolitan Opera's restaurant workers is planning to turn tonight's season opener into a face-off between blue-blooded opera lovers and the blue-collar workers who often earn poverty-level wages serving them food. Shortly before the curtain rises, hundreds of people from a dozen unions are scheduled to hold a rally in a small park across from Lincoln Center, where the opera house is situated. Their strategy is to embarrass the Met and its high-society patrons so that they will pressure Restaurant Associates, the contractor at the Met, to grant recognition to Local 100 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union.

headline.main: Union Tries to Get Support By Shaming Opera Fans

docs.lead_paragraph: Saint Barnabas Health Care System, the state's largest health care system and its third largest private employer, will reduce its staff by 500 to help make up for financial losses of $44 million last year, according to Ellen Greene, a spokeswoman. Most of the employees affected, including 50 in corporate positions, are being transferred to other open jobs. None of the health care system's 10 hospitals and nine nursing homes will be closed.

headline.main: St. Barnabas Health Care To Eliminate 500 Jobs

docs.lead_paragraph: While labor unions have weakened in many industries, last year's strike against General Motors showed that auto workers can still cripple production at the world's largest companies. Now DaimlerChrysler's new, four-year contract with the United Automobile Workers, details of which came out last Monday, show just how generous the compensation can be for workers in such a strong bargaining position:

docs.lead_paragraph: With a behind-the-scenes boost from John Cardinal O'Connor, a campaign to unionize New York's nearly 12,000 black-car drivers took a major step forward this week when a limousine company that has fought unionization for two years signed a union contract. The company, Last Radio Group, reached an agreement with the drivers' union after the Cardinal wrote letters to several Wall Street firms -- among the biggest customers of limousine companies -- to urge them to patronize unionized companies that provide health insurance and other benefits.

headline.main: Cardinal Helps Propel Bid to Unionize Limousine Drivers

docs.lead_paragraph: The Giuliani administration is planning to search thousands of medical billing records for evidence it can use to place welfare applicants in mandatory drug and alcohol treatment programs as a condition of receiving public assistance, city welfare officials say. The information will be culled from computerized Medicaid insurance bills submitted in the past on behalf of applicants who have voluntarily sought treatment for drug and alcohol problems. The record search is for the applicants' own good, welfare officials said this week, and will be used to push them to finish treatment and to get jobs faster.

headline.main: Welfare Officials To Search Records Of Drug Treatment

docs.abstract: Giuliani administration will search thousands of medical billing records for evidence it can use to place welfare applicants i mandatory drug and alcohol treeatment programs as a condition for receiving public assistance; says current system of drug screening and testing is finding unrealistically low rates of substance abuse among welfare mothers who need help; privacy experts and lawyers for the poor says searches could violate Federal law, might frighten poor people from seeking seeking treatment or benefits and will send a chilling message to anyone considering help for drug or alcohol problems (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration has chosen one of the nation's leading experts on AIDS policy to run Medicaid, the health insurance program for poor people and the disabled, Administration officials said today. The expert, Timothy M. Westmoreland, a 45-year-old lawyer, said he would begin work on Oct. 18 as director of the Center for Medicaid and State Operations, a unit of the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline.main: A Top Expert on AIDS Policy Is Appointed to Run Medicaid

docs.abstract: Timothy M Westmoreland, one of nation's leading experts on AIDS policy, is named director of Center for Medicaid and State Operations, unit of Department of Health and Human Services; he will also supervise Children's Health Insurance Program, created in 1997 to provide coverage for uninsured children not eligible for Medicaid; photo (M)
